author: Robert Gibson
title: North East CBI warns on Brexit risk to aims of Northern Powerhouse - Chronicle Live
text:
North East CBI warns on Brexit risk to aims of Northern Powerhouse 00:02, 16 Jun 2016 By Robert Gibson Letter sent to Northern media says UK access to EU markets is a major critical factor for foreign investors Shares Get business news by email Sarah Glendinning, director, CBI North East 
Senior Northern figures in the employers’ organisation CBI have warned that Brexit could seriously jeopardise the aims of the Northern Powerhouse . 
North East regional director Sarah Glendinning, as well as Alison Thain, chair of the CBI North East Council, have signed an open letter, along with their counterparts in the North West and in Yorkshire and Humberside. 
The letter, which comes with a week until the EU referendum, highlights the risk the organisation sees to jobs in the North if the UK leaves the European Union. 
It says: “The economy is one of a number of issues people will consider when voting in the EU Referendum. 
“Business creates jobs and economic growth. That is as true in the North as it is anywhere else. Most business group polls conclude that a majority of small, medium and large companies want to remain in the EU. 
“The economic consensus is clear too – we should expect a Brexit to induce a sharp shock that could leave the UK economy smaller in future.” 
The CBI supported the Government’s efforts to secure economic growth outside of London, the letter said. 
The organisation also agreed with the goals of the Northern Powerhouse, as “better transport and education will create greater opportunities for companies based here and more jobs”. 
“Investment from abroad is critical to this,” the letter continued. “Recent analysis shows northern-based foreign direct investment projects experienced 127% growth over the last two years. 
“Many foreign investors cite access to EU markets as a critical factor in their UK investment decisions. 
“So, we must recognise that reduced market access could slow regional investment.” 
The letter said there were “clear signs” the North had been making progress in recent years. 
“Putting that trend of rising investment at risk would put growth and jobs in our region in jeopardy, undermining the North’s potential to become a true powerhouse,” it concluded. 
In an interview with The Journal, Ms Glendinning pointed that the idea of Brexit potentially compromising future growth had been reinforced by a recent survey by accountancy group EY. 
And, while the North East had a strong record when it came to exporting to places such as China and India, the European Single Market represented a £5bn-a-year opportunity, particularly through trade with countries such as Italy, Belgium, Spain and the Netherlands. 
Businesses of all sizes - not just large firms like Hitachi and Virgin Money - could benefit from this, and, particularly in sectors like automotive, the impact on the supply chain was considerable, she said. 
“This is one of the biggest decisions many of us will get to make in our lifetimes,” she said. “So it is absolutely incumbent upon employers to be talking about the impact of the referendum result. 
“They should also make sure they provide opportunities for employees to vote, whether that is through shift changes or just through providing a bit more flexibility.” 
It was crucial, she added, that voters were in possession of the facts. 
“There are lots of reasons upon which people will base their decisions, but the overwhelming view from economic experts - who don’t always agree with each other - that for jobs, prosperity and growth, we should be remaining in the UK,” she said.
